From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Simon Chappell
Sent: Friday, March 24, 2006 2:15 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Help Required

 

On 3/20/06, Adnan Ahmed <write4leo@...> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> i am new in junit and want to use in one of my project
> for testing purpose. can anyone tell me any good
> tutorial or kick start resource to learn about junit.
>
> Thanks

Welcome to the wonderful world of JUnit!

There are many useful websites for the JUnit user, but perhaps the two
main ones are http://www.junit.org/ <http://www.junit.org/>  and
http://www.google.com/. <http://www.google.com/>  The
JUnit site maintains a lot of useful information and links to other
resources. Many of the articles there are directed towards the
beginner and will help you greatly as you learn about JUnit. Google is
useful when there's something you need, but don't know what it is.
Just type a description in, press enter and see how much help it can
be. I've found quite a few useful things that way. Another tip with
Google is to search on the specific error message that you have, often
you'll find forum discussions about that exact error, with a good
chance of a solution being given as well.

As you learn and start having questions, you will also find the JUnit
FAQ very helpful. The questions that it answers really are the
frequent ones that most of us had asked or wondered about and Mike
Clark does a wonderful job of collating it. Here is a link:

http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm
<http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm> 

When you are ready to start asking more questions on the JUnit mailing
list, please consider following all of the advice in Eric Raymond's
very helpful document: "How to ask questions the smart way", available
at his website. Here is a link:

http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html
<http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html> 

As far as books are concerned, I recommend Pragmatic Unit Testing by
Hunt and Thomas for beginners. JUnit recipes by Rainsberger is good
once you're past the basics. There are other good books out there, but
these are my recommendations.

I hope that this helps.

Simon

--
www.simonpeter.org
